author: perama
content:
The diagram could have two shadows over the purple mempool side - curves which represent the maximum and minimum possible basefee possible. 

That is, if the fee changed every block in one direction (say lower) the shadow line curves down and to the right. You can see that after ten blocks the curve is at basefee X.

Looking at the mempool tx's relative to that lower-bound curve, you could see the likelihood of that event, based on whether the tx's are above or below that line.

The converse example might be:
- The upper bound curve is projected out ten blocks
- The mempool tx's are above that curve for all those ten blocks
- one can ascertain that the projection is accurate. 
- zooming out to 20 blocks, you can see that the tx's are below the curve at 18 blocks worth of tx's. 
- one can ascertain that this might be an estimate of when the basefee might stop rising
- fast forward to that time (18 blocks in the future) the basefee is now at a new higher level
- the mempool transactions are above the minimum curve, above the current basefee, but below the maximum curve
- one can ascertain that the current basefee is stable at the new level for now

author: perama
content:
Imagine a small program that simulates the mechanics of this, where:

- a user can press buttons to control the mempool
- the diagram changes with each button press 
- blocks pass every 2 seconds
- pressing "2" adds 100 txs at 20 gwei
- pressing "9" "9" adds 200txs at 90 gwei
- pressing "shift+9" adds 100txs at 900 gwei
- if you stop pressing buttons you can quickly see and "feel" how the rate changes
- if you mash the number pad and make a mega mempool, you can see how that manifests and tops out

I'll have a think and might mock up a script to do this if I have some time
